title: Older coal-fired power stations a better bet, says Trevor St Baker
text:
Mr St Baker said it made sense to keep coal-fired plants operating because the economics stacked up – they had already been paid for and still had a robust shelf life.

"That's the current cheapest capital that's already been paid off,'' he said.

The Vales Point plant was a perfect case study.

"We already have a program for extending the life of that [Vales Point] for another 20 years. The cost of that is $750 million and to replace it with a new plant would be $2 billion."

The bedrock

Coal-fired plants were the bedrock of keeping energy costs down and retaining jobs in Australia, he said.

"If we don't keep it going, we won't keep business and jobs in this country."

Mr St Baker dismissed the need for Australia to do more to reach international climate targets, saying it was more important to protect jobs and the economy.

"All of this pantomime that goes on about how we have to have 100 per cent sun and wind," he said, was not focusing on the big issue of power reliability.

Grattan Institute energy program director Tony Wood said that instead of squeezing coal-fired power stations out of the market early, they should be allowed to reach the end of their natural life.

"I think it's more about a commercial life. I think technical life is really irrelevant,'' he said.

Mr Wood said problems emerged when governments started intervening.

"The problem is that as soon as governments become worried, they start doing stuff,'' he said.

Australian Energy Council chief executive Sarah McNamara agreed, saying that ideology should be stripped out of the whole debate about the future of coal.

"I don't think ideology is very helpful when it comes to talking about our energy mix,'' she said.

"We should be technology neutral. Coal is absolutely 100 per cent going to be part of our energy mix through to 2050."
description: Keeping older coal-fired plants operating for longer makes economic sense and will help keep jobs in Australia, the coal baron says.
